definitions.definition: to provide somebody with the money that they need in order to do something

examples.text: A bank loan helped to set him up in business.

definitions.definition: to make somebody healthier, stronger, more lively, etc.

examples.text: The break from work really set me up for the new year.

definitions.definition: to trick somebody, especially by making them appear guilty of something

examples.text: He denied the charges, saying the police had set him up.

definitions.definition: to create something or start it

examples.text: A fund will be set up for the dead men's families.

definitions.definition: to build something or put something somewhere

examples.text: The police set up roadblocks on routes out of the city.

definitions.definition: to make a piece of equipment or a machine ready for use

examples.text: She set up her guitar and amp in her bedroom.

definitions.definition: to arrange for something to happen

examples.text: I've set up a meeting for Friday.

definitions.definition: to start a process or a series of events

examples.text: The slump on Wall Street set up a chain reaction in stock markets around the world.
She took out a bank loan and set up on her own.
After leaving college, he set himself up as a freelance photographer.
